The best way to test the effects of different levels of roll and polar inertia on a vehicle's performance on smooth and rough off-road tracks is to conduct on-track testing using the actual vehicle and track conditions. This can help you determine the optimal balance of inertias for a given vehicle and track, and can also provide valuable data that can be used to refine the vehicle's design and improve its performance.

Here are some general steps that can help you conduct effective on-track testing for roll and polar inertias:

1. Start by gathering data on the off-road track where the vehicle will be tested. This can include information on the track's layout, surface conditions, and any other factors that may affect the vehicle's performance.
2. Use this data to create a mathematical model of the vehicle and the track. This can help you predict the vehicle's behavior under different conditions and identify areas where improvements can be made.
3. Experiment with different levels of roll and polar inertia in the vehicle's design. This may involve changing the vehicle's suspension, body shape, or other components to achieve the desired inertias.
4. Test the vehicle on the track to see how it performs with different inertias. This can help you determine the optimal balance of inertias for the given vehicle and track.
5. Repeat the design and testing process as needed until you achieve the best compromise between smooth and rough track performance. This may require multiple iterations and a lot of trial and error, but it will ultimately lead to a more balanced and effective off-road vehicle.
